This group of 11 entrepreneurs all live in the same building in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their second loan with ALIDE.

Christine (with her hand raised in the photo) was born in 1965 in Adjarra to the north of Benin. She moved to Cotonou 12 years ago. A widow, she still cares for two of her six children.

For the past 12 years Christine has run a stall selling fish and meat meals. This loan will enable her to purchase raw ingredients directly from the lake and markets. Her aim in the long term is to grow her business to be able to fully care for her children's needs. She claims to have strong management skills and a thorough approach to completing her tasks.

loans.use: to purchase fish, meat, and condiments to prepare meals for sale.

loans.name: Sali

texts.fr:
Madame  Sali Koné est âgée de 39 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants, elle vit dans une famille polygame  à Koutiala Darsalam II.   
Pour des raisons sociales, Madame Sali n’a pas eu la chance d’étudier, ce qui justifie son intégration dans le commerce qu’elle a appris auprès de sa mère depuis à bas âge. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, elle s’est intéressée  à la vente d’articles divers  depuis 11 ans. 
Pour augmenter la taille de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, Madame Sali a décidé de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso pour atteindre ses objectifs.  Après  2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement elle est à son  deuxième prêt individuel, le premier a été bien remboursé. 
Elle compte améliorer ses stocks de  marchandises et ses ventes, avec ce prêt, en achetant une importante quantité de chaussures, de tissus ; de tasses,  etc.  
Elle s’approvisionne à Cotonou et effectue sa vente dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle mixte, au comptant et à crédit.  Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 120.000FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement de son échéance, participer aux charges quotidiennes de la famille et poursuivre son activité avec le reste.
texts.en:
Ms. Sali Koné is 39 years old, married and a mother of 5 children.  She lives in a polygamous family in Koutiala Darsalam II.

Social factors prevented Ms. Sali from being able to go to school, which led to her becoming part of the business she learned from her mother at a young age.  Eleven years ago, after running several businesses unsuccessfully, she became interested in the sale of a range of various items.

Aiming to grow her business and meet her customers’ demand, Ms. Sali decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to help her meet her goals.  She is currently on her second individual loan, having participated in two group loans, both fully reimbursed, and a first individual loan, also reimbursed.

She plans on using this loan to increase her inventory and sales, by buying a bulk quantity of shoes, fabric, cups, etc.

She buys supplies at Cotonou and sells them in the town of Koutiala to a diverse clientele, for cash or on credit.  She is aiming for monthly profits of 120,000 CFA francs, which she will use to reimburse her loan and contribute to her family’s daily needs, with the rest going towards continuing her business.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of items for inventory

loans.name: Sidiki

texts.fr:
Monsieur Sidiki S. est âgé de 46 ans et vit dans une famille polygame avec ses  épouses et ses 6 enfants  dans le quartier Lafiala  de la préfecture de Koutiala. 
Du à des problèmes de famille, il a prématurément abandonné l’école pour s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus depuis son enfance. Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans réussite, il s’est finalement intéressé à la vente de poissons fumés qu’il appris auprès de son père il y a 20 ans. Les poissons fumés sont très prisés à Koutiala.  
Pour pouvoir  augmenter son fonds de commerce et renforcer sa capacité de vente, il a décidé de rejoindre  l‘institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso, et il est à son premier prêt individuel. Avec ce financement, il compte acheter  4 paniers de poissons fumés  à Korientzé  (Région de Mopti) auprès des  pêcheurs d’ethnie  Bozo  et  Somono. Monsieur Sidiki  effectue sa vente au  marché poisson de Koutiala  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’ hommes,  au comptant et à crédit. Avec ce financement il compte  réaliser un profit de 70000FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera  pour  le remboursement des intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, satisfaire les besoins  de sa  famille et investir le reste dans son activité
texts.en:
Mr. Sidiki S. is 46 years old and lives in a polygamous family with his wives and his six children in the Lafiala district of Koutiala prefecture. Due to some family problems, he quit school prematurely and became interested in revenue-generating businesses since he was young.  After having run several businesses unsuccessfully, he was ultimately interested in selling smoked fish. This was something he learned from his father twenty years ago. Smoked fish is highly prized in Koutiala.  

To be able to increase his business capital and to bolster his selling capacity, Sidiki decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. He is now on his first individual loan. With this financing, he intends to buy 4 baskets of smoked fish in Korientzé (Region of Mopti) from fisher folk of the Bozo and Somono ethnic groups. He makes his sales at the Koutiala fish market. He accepts cash or credit from a customer base composed of women and men. 

With this financing, Sidiki plans on making a profit of 70,000 francs CFA per month that he will use to cover the Soro Yiriwaso loan interest and to satisfy the needs of his family. The rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: to buy smoked fish

loans.name: Delphine's Group

texts.en:
This group of 11 entrepreneurs all live in the same building in Cotonou, Benin's largest city. This is their second loan with ALIDE.

Delphine, the leader of the group (with her hand raised in the photo), was born in 1985 in Comé near the border to Togo. She moved to her current location three years ago and now lives with her husband, Casimir, and their three children.

Since the age of 10, Delphine has helped prepare food for sale, which she now does outside her home. This loan will enable her to purchase ingredients such as rice and oil from Tokpa, Benin's largest market. Her aim in the long term is to continue strengthening her business. She claims to be strong in managing her business and the group.

loans.use: to purchase rice and oil for cooking meals to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy fabrics, perfumes, and seasonal products for resale
